review.title: Natural Language Generation enhances human decision-making with uncertain information
review.abstract: Decision-making is often dependent on uncertain data, e.g. data associated with confidence scores or probabilities. We present a comparison of different information presentations for uncertain data and, for the first time, measure their effects on human decision-making. We show that the use of Natural Language Generation (NLG) improves decision-making under uncertainty, compared to state-of-the-art graphical-based representation methods. In a task-based study with 442 adults, we found that presentations using NLG lead to 24% better decision-making on average than the graphical presentations, and to 44% better decision-making when NLG is combined with graphics. We also show that women achieve significantly better results when presented with NLG output (an 87% increase on average compared to graphical presentations).
histories: 54th annual meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics (ACL), Berlin 2016

metadata.title: Natural Language Generation enhances human decision-making with uncertain information

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In this paper, we examine whether the technology can also be used to support decision-making when the underlying data is uncertain.

sections.heading: 2 The Extended Weather Game
sections.text: In this section, we present our enhanced version of the MetOffice weather game (Stephens et al., 2011), where the player must choose where to send an ice cream seller to maximize sales given the weather forecast for four weeks and two locations. These forecasts describe (1) predicted precipitation (Figure 2) and (2) temperature levels along with their probabilities in three ways: (a) by graphs (which is the version of the original game), (b) by textual predictions and (c) by combined graphical and textual predictions. We created the text format using two rules-based NLG approaches as described in the next section. Users are asked to first select the best target for the ice cream seller and then specify how confident they are with their choice. Based on their choices and their confidence level, participants are eventually presented with their "monetary gain." For example, the higher the probability of sunshine is, the higher the monetary gain if the player declares at the end that the game is not actually raining and the probability that it is.

sections.heading: 3 Natural Language Generation from
sections.text: Uncertain information We developed two NLG systems, WMO-based and NATURAL, using SimpleNLG (Gatt and Reiter, 2009), which both generate textual descriptions of precipitation and temperature data that address the uncertain nature of forecasts. WMO-based: This is a rules-based system that uses the guidelines recommended by the WMO (Kootval, 2008) to report uncertainties, as in Table 1. For example, consider a forecast of sunny intervals with a 30% chance of rain. This WMO-based system generates the following forecast: "Sunny intervals with possible rain - less likely than not." NATURAL: This system mimics predictions and their natural nature of weather reporting. The rules applied in this system were derived from observing the way experts (e.g. BBC weather reporters) make predictions. For the previous example, all of this system will be sunny with a 30% probability of rain.

sections.heading: 4 Evaluation
sections.text: In order to investigate what helps people better understand and respond to uncertainties in information presentations, we use five conditions in the context of the Extended Weather Game: 1. Graphic only: This representation only shows users the graphical representation of weather forecasts. For this condition, we used the graphs that performed best in terms of human understanding (Stephens et al., 2011). 2. Multimodal representation: − Graphic and NATURAL: This is a multimodal representation consisting of graphics (as described in the previous state) and text produced by the NATURAL system. − Graphic and WMO-based: This is also a multimodal representation consisting of graphics and text produced by the WMObased system. 3. Only NLG: − Only NATURAL: This is a purely text-based representation as described above. − Only WMO-based system: This is also a purely text-based representation.

sections.heading: 5 Data
sections.text: We recruited 442 unique players (197 females1, 241 male, 4 undisclosed) via social media. We collected 450 unique gaming instances (only a few players played the game twice) and the anonymized data will be released as part of this submission.

sections.heading: 6 Results
sections.text: In order to investigate which representations support people in making decisions under uncertainty, we analysed both the players "outcomes (in terms of financial gain) and their predictions of the impact on their confidence scores. As we described in Section 2, the game calculates a financial gain based on both the decisions and the player's confidence, i.e. the player's ability to make decisions. In terms of confidence, we asked users to declare their confidence on a 10-point scale. Therefore, in our analysis, we focus on both confidence and score in the game.1 Women accounted for 44.5% of the subjects.

sections.heading: 6.1 Results for all adults
sections.text: Multimodal vs. pure graphics: We found that the use of multimodal graphics resulted in a significantly higher score (i.e. better decision-making) than pure graphics (p = 0.03, effect = + 36.36), which is an average 44% increase in score. Multimodal vs. pure NLG: However, there is no significant difference between pure graphics and pure graphics in terms of score. NLG vs. pure graphics: We found that the NLG graphics resulted in an increase in average task result (i.e. better decision-making) of 24.8% compared to pure graphics, see Table 2: an average score increase of over 20 points. There was no significant difference between WMO and NATURAL NLG conditions. Confidence: For confidence: Multimodal graphics are significantly more effective than pure graphics (<01; effect = 17.7%).

sections.heading: 6.2 Results for Females
sections.text: We found that women performed significantly better on the decision task when exposed to one of the NLG output presentations compared to the pure graphics presentation (p < 0.05, effect = + 53.03), an increase of 87%, see also Table 3. In addition, the same user group achieved significantly higher scores when presented with only the multimodal output compared to the pure graphics (p = 0.05, effect = 60.74%). Interestingly, for this group, the multimodal presentation contributes little more to decision-making effectiveness than the pure NLG condition, but the multimodal presentations increase their confidence (+ 15%). Furthermore, we found that educated (i.e., with a BSc or higher degree) women who also correctly answered the risk literacy test felt significantly more confident with the multimodal presentation than with the NLG alone (p = 0.01, effect = 16.7%).

sections.heading: 6.3 Results for Males
sections.text: We found that men scored similar scores for all types of representation, suggesting that the improved scores shown above (for all adults) are largely due to the beneficial effects of NLG for women. In terms of confidence, men are more likely to be more confident when presented with graphs (81% of the time) or multimodal representation (85% of the time) (p = 0.01).

sections.heading: 7 Conclusions and Future Work
sections.text: We present the results of a game-based study on the generation of descriptions of uncertain data - a problem that has not been studied by data-to-text systems to date. We note that there is a significant gender gap between multimodal, NLG and graphical versions of the task, with the use of NLG in women resulting in an 87% increase in task success over graphics. Multimodal presentations result in a 44% increase in all adults compared to graphics. People are also more confident when using multimodal representations, as reported in (Foster and Oberlander, 2006; Rieser and Lemon, 2008; Weiß et al., 2012). The results are also related to educational research showing that women perform better in verbal-gender tasks than visual-spatial ones (Zhu, 2007; Zhu, a study of future behavior).

referenceMentions.context: Natural Language Generation (NLG) technology can achieve comparable results to commonly used data visualisation techniques for supporting accurate human decision-making (Gatt et al., 2009).

Current data-to-text systems assume that the underlying data is precise and correct – an assumption which is heavily criticised by other disciplines concerned with decision support, such as medicine (Gigerenzer and Muir Gray, 2011), environmental modelling (Beven, 2009), climate change (Manning et al., 2004), or weather forecasting (Kootval, 2008).
We then evaluate the strategies against a state-of-the-art graphical system (Stephens et al., 2011), which presents the uncertain data in a graphical way.
We use a gamebased setup (Gkatzia et al., 2015) to perform taskbased evaluation, to investigate the effect that the different information presentation strategies have on human decision-making.
